article_text:
A new wave of retirement planning tools seeks to connect employees to their 401(k) plans by tapping into their hearts rather than their heads.

Spurred by the work of behavioral economists, the tools guide employees to consider an older version of themselves.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: Dan Berman
article_metadata.description: Some in a study were shown age-enhanced photos of themselves while others did not see such images. Those that looked at their old age squarely in the face put an average of 6.8 percent of their salary in their 401(k)s. Those that didn’t deferred 5.2 percent.
